definition:
A function $f:\mathbb{N}\rightarrow\mathbb{N}$ is *time constructible*
if there is a deterministic Turing machine $T$ (with alphabet
$\{0,1,B\}$) such that when $T$ receives as input the a series of $n$
ones, it halts after exactly $f(n)$ steps. Similarly $f$ is *space
constructible* if there is a similar Turing machine which halts after
using exactly $f(n)$ cells.

Most ’natural’ functions are both time and space constructible,
including constant functions, polynomials, and exponentials, for
example.
